author: @WernerBeroux
text: There is a long term question of the feedback loop. All these are built on top of the open internet, but if all answers are from the GPT, then questions will not get on the open internet and people will not try to provide model answers. Then how will these models work? Same for discussions. If we switch from a human to human to a human to GPT then only that GPT model may improve over time as it's the only one that'll have the human inputs (until we don't need humans input at all in another model).

author: @peteroliver7975
text: I asked ChatGPT the following question: "Will Google be able to compete with Microsoft once Bing has incorporated ChatGPT?" ChatGPT responded with this answer:  "It is difficult to predict with certainty how Google and Microsoft's competition in the search engine market will be affected by the incorporation of ChatGPT into Bing.  While ChatGPT is a powerful language model, search engines are complex systems that rely on many factors beyond just natural language processing. Both Google and Microsoft have invested heavily in their search algorithms, infrastructure, and user experience, and they have large user bases and established brand recognition.  Additionally, the integration of ChatGPT into Bing is just one potential development in the ongoing competition between the two companies. Google and Microsoft are likely to continue innovating and refining their search engines in response to each other and changing user needs and expectations.  Overall, while ChatGPT may give Bing an edge in certain areas, it is unlikely to be a decisive factor in the long-term competition between Google and Microsoft."

author: @initiallblast
text: For Chinese companies, they have a handicap or disadvantage compared to Western companies in the field of AI. They operate under the strict censorship and surveillance of the Chinese government. As amazing as AI technology may be in the eyes of the private sector, it remains a serious threat to a government that wants to maintain absolute control over the way its people think and narrate. In short, the Chinese government, as a Communist government with a population of around 1.4 billion people, is sensitive to issues that may invite their anger.  Chat GPT, this is a bit tricky guys. It is vulnerable to inviting the wrath of the government. For example, if Baidu creates an AI chatbot like Chat GPT and a Chinese user asks the chatbot, "What is your opinion on the 1989 Tiananmen Square incident?" This is a very sensitive issue for the Chinese government, as it ended with a massacre in China. If the chatbot's response seems to insult the government, then Baidu will get into big trouble with the government. But IF THE QUESTION IS CENSORED, THE CHATBOT WILL LOSE CREDIBILITY IN THE EYES OF THE USER.

author: @chansakabwe6956
text: The scary thing about LLM enhanced search is that the big losers are likely the content creators who write blog posts and text content. If an LLM chatbot like ChatGPT can generate a blog post you're looking for, then there won't be need for you to visit the site(s) where you get that information from. As an Engineer, I use StackOverflow sometimes, so if I get my queries answered by a chatbot I don't have to go and start looking for answers on StackOverflow. Thereby, StackOverflow loses a dozens of my potential visits in the month. The same applies to sites like medium which is my go-to for interesting articles to read. Overall, when LLM-based chatbots get the hallucination and search problems right, they'll be the scariest things for content creators and resource sites.

author: @shanesteven4578
text: Google is and always has been complacent about its market position. I’m currently using New Bing after moving away from bog-standard Google. If my experience is anything to go by, I’ve completely stopped using Google Search and my work flow is now 100% done through Bing. I have found almost no reason to use Google Search. I have no issues with, or axe’s to grind against Google, I am simply stating my experience with the New Bing way of doing my work and I cannot rate New Bing highly enough. Yes, there are some small issues with its first incarnation, and there are some things I’d love to see added to help my workflow move even faster, but I’m loving this new way of working and I have never been more excited for, or optimistic about, the future. Thank you Bing (Microsoft) & OpenAI.

text: Yea, I found it really interesting that a couple weeks ago (3, it looks like), Sam Altman gave a rare interview with StrictlyVC about investing and quite a bit on OpenAI (since ChatGPT was so big). And there was an offhand comment when he was asked about Google saying that they wouldn't deploy their model because it's too imperfect and would do too much damage to their reputations. And Altman kind of just scoffed and said something like 'I hope, when they launch something anyway, that you hold them to that'.  He knew what was coming real soon and sure enough, Google scrambled to have anything at all. We'll see if that all ends up being better or not..

author: @FinGeek4now
text: There are two problems with AI text generation that I can think of. The first and biggest problem is that the models need to be trained with up-to-date information and that training takes time. The biggest improvement in this space would be a model that can train itself and give the best answer at that moment in real-time. If I was to make something like this, I would include a "confidence" score before displaying the answer to the user and if that score is below a certain threshold, scour the web for up-to-date information about the topic. If the information is in-line with the generated answer, display the text. If not, then generate the text around the up-to-date information, then lower the priority of previous answers while increasing the priority of the new information, then re-train and deploy. Another way to do it would be through daily updates, where the model gets information, trains and then deploys that model once complete, which it does ad-infinitum. The problem with this is to moderating the model and making sure that the model is accurate :\  The second problem is accuracy of the generated text, which can be solved simply by telling the user how accurate the answer is and including a counter-point answer and including that answer too. For example, if asked "What is the the best way to do XYZ", the answer given would be along the lines of, "There is an 65% chance that the best way to do XYZ is to do ABC, however, there is also a 20% chance that the best way to do it would be to do it would be DEF. There are other ways to do XYZ, however, those are the best methods I've found."

author: @MrBoubource
text: Honestly the headlines were misleading about JWST capturing its first images of an exoplanet. "First exoplanet captured by JWST" can have 2 meanings, if you don't know there already were photos of exoplanets (wich I didn't), you would think JWST took the first one (wich I did).  Google cherry picked a challenging prompt without knowing, their AI failed, and they didn't fact check their screenshot. Big oopsie from a 1 trillion dollar company.

author: @alexmchugh8082
text: I do think the Bard announcement was rather rushed and seemed quite unprepared. However I think the criticism of the JWST answer is a little too harsh. Technically and syntactically, the answer was in fact correct although sounds somewhat unnatural in everyday human speech. The JWST did take the very first pictures of a planet outside our solar system. This is true when speaking about a specific planet, which it is, but sounds to us like its claiming the first pictures of *any* planet outside our solar system, which it's not.

author: @japa8111
text: I quickly searched google for "Who actually took the first picture of an exoplanet?" and the first 2 hits are pages from NASA which state: 1st page: 2M1207b is the first exoplanet directly imaged and the first discovered orbiting a brown dwarf. It was imaged the first time by the VLT in 2004; 2nd page: For the first time, astronomers have used NASA's James Webb Space Telescope to take a direct image of a planet outside our solar system. So in a first glance it seems that even NASA is not sure. However, actually reading both statements everything becomes clear. I would say it is a subtle difference in saying who took the first ever image of the exoplanet and that JSW took the first image of the exoplanet.

author: @kimeg7294
text: Feeding the "right" information is not easy, it requires human intelligence and effort to sort out most (if not all) of the "wrong" info. Different fields require different measures on how they want to categorize right and wrong info, thus they need experts from each specific field to do this, which is very expensive. Also, these experts will highly likely disagree on the opinions of one another, which makes this process nearly unattainable.
